list_page_teaser: Norm Peterson and Lilith Sternin have extreme personalities and are total opposites.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
Norm's personality is similar to the personalities of Woody, Coach, and Rebecca — but much more extreme. Cliff's personality is similar to Sam's — but the mail man is a bit less down-to-earth than the bar owner.

Frasier's personality is similar to Diane's — but he's a bit more down-to-earth than she is. And Lilith's personality is an extreme one — and the polar opposite of Norm's.
story_html:
While re-watching the series, I distinctly remember seeing Norm and Lilith have a conversation and thinking, Lilith and Norm are opposites! Now, having performed a formal analysis of their personalities and drawn the images, it is gratifying to see how extreme their differences are.

Unfortunately Cliff's portrait does not show what an annoying weirdo he is. An episode in which Frazier meets Cliff's mom Esther, and comments that Cliff suddenly seemed almost heroically well-adjusted, is quite revealing, but the image does not capture that.

The similarites between Frasier and Diane were obvious from the start. It's almost as if the show's creators, producers, and writers knew she would be leaving the show, and brought him in to replace her, to provide the same sort of psychological tension.

And finally, Lilith is indeed quite a singular character. Viewers gain insight into how she got that way in the episode Smotherly Love, when Lilith's mom Betty pays her a visit. Notably, Betty is one of the few characters able to insult Carla and leave her speechless, totally without a comback!

It took a long time to watch all 271 episodes of the series and create these images, but I am pleased with the results. It seems only natural to follow up with other popular sitcoms, Seinfeld (173 episodes), Friends (236 episodes), and maybe even The Honeymooners (39 episodes), Will and Grace (224 episodes), M*A*S*H (251 episodes), or I Love Lucy (181 episodes).

To keep up to date and learn when I add those and other shows to the site, follow us on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Norm Peterson
image_list.subtitle_html: Barfly at Cheers
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Norm Peterson's spiritual portrait shows he is friendly and extremely open to new experiences.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Norm's dominant personality trait, his openness to new experiences.  His preference is so strong it is actually a need for stimulation.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Norm demonstrates this trait in the way he is more interested in what people do than in what they think.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Norm's auxiliary personality trait, his friendliness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he is warm and friendly to eveyone, even Lilith, whose personality is opposite to his in every way.
image_list.story_intro_html: Norm Peterson is Cheers' most faithful patron. He appeared in all 275 episodes and was frequently greeted with a chorus of ....
image_list.story_html:
Norm Peterson is Cheers' most faithful patron. He appeared in all 275 episodes and was frequently greeted with a chorus of people yelling Norm! when he walked into the bar. His best friend is Cliff Clavin, a proud postal worker, and for Norm more than for anyone else, Cheers is a place where everybody knows your name.

Norm's Extreme Personality

Norm Peterson's spiritual portrait is a sea of Yellow, showing he is very realistic and open to new experiences. He may not care for Cliff's and Diane's wild ideas at times, but — unlike Carla — he does not judge them, he just goes along with the flow.

Norm is possibly the most laid back person we will ever meet. In the episode The Mail Goes to Jail, Norm and Cliff have a very serious falling out. However, being relatively easy-going people, they are able to quickly resolve their differences and resume their friendship.

Norm's personality may be extreme, but this particular type of extremeness is not very noticible. This is because it is not exceptional in a harsh, judgemental way, but rather in an open and easy-going way.

Norm as Everyman

Like the viewers at home, Norm Peterson is passive — he sees it all but rarely makes decisions. This is the essence of what Yellow represents in these spiritual portraits: pure perception. As Jimi Hendrix put it so plainly in his song Up From the Skies: I want to see and hear everything.

Viewers are in the same boat — like Norm, viewers turn to Cheers because we have nothing better to do and crave entertainment — so it is easy for us to relate to him.

Frasier Crane: You know it just isn't fair. I came because I wanted to be one of the guys and all I'm doing is sitting on my duff watching other people do things.
Norm Peterson: Welcome to NormWorld. Keep your hands inside the car at all times.
 — From Indoor Fun with Sammy and Robby, 1990.

Norm is an everyman — an individual with whom it is easy for people to identify. In The Executive's Executioner, Norm's boss puts him in charge of telling people when they are laid off, because he is an ordinary Joe who has absolutely nothing that anyone could ever envy or resent.

In essence, Norm's extreme openness acts as a channel, helping viewers feel more like we're in the bar. As an easy-going barfly, ultimately Norm serves as a proxy for us viewers.

Norm and Lilith: Polar Opposites

Norm Peterson's personality is the polar opposite of Lilith Sternin's. While Norm is outgoing, down-to-earth, warm, and open, Lilith is withdrawn, comfortable with abstractions, cold, and decisive.

Lilith's personality and spiritual portrait are also extreme, but in the opposite direction from Norm's. The two have nothing in common other than being patrons of Cheers, and no real reason to even talk to each other. But in one scene when they do have occasion to talk, they get along just fine — because they have nothing to argue about.

Although Norm's and Lilith's characters are fictional — and even extreme to the point of being caricatures — their spiritual portraits can give us insight into the less extreme personalities of real life people.

Understanding Norm's and Lilith's images and their relationship gives us a reason to be optimistic. If two people who have such extremely different personalities can manage to get along, maybe someday more evenly-balanced, normal people can someday figure out how to get along together as well.

Here's a hint: helping people understand each other's differences and hopefully get along better as a result is, in actuality, ultimately the whole purpose of this site.

image_list.title: Cliff Clavin
image_list.subtitle_html: Postal Worker and Barfly at Cheers
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Cliff Clavin's spiritual portrait shows he is outgoing, pragmatic, and logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Cliff's dominant personality trait, his preference for facts over ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrates this trait in his habit of frequently interjecting obscure and sometimes questionable trivia into conversations at the bar.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Cliff's auxiliary personality trait, his preference for logic over emotion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he rarely shows emotion, and sometimes even resorts to incoherent blubbering when in the presence of a woman he is attracted to.
image_list.story_intro_html: Cliff Clavin is one of Cheers' most loyal patrons. He is proud to be a postal worker, and Norm Peterson is his best friend. The Yellow and Blue in his image shows ....
image_list.story_html:
Cliff Clavin is one of Cheers' most loyal patrons. He is proud to be a postal worker, and Norm Peterson is his best friend. The Yellow and Blue in his image shows he can be accepting of most people — with one notable exception being he will not tolerate anyone putting down the United States Postal Service.

Cliff's Openness to Facts and Ideas

The Yellow in Cliff Clavin's spiritual portrait indicates he is very open to new facts, and the Blue shows he is also open to new ideas. As a result, Cliff considers himself knowledgable about a great number of things.

When Cliff's wellspring of trivia combines with his outgoing personality, he can frequently be heard saying the strangest, most esoteric, and totally irrelevant things — much to the easily-annoyed Carla's dismay.

Cliff: Well, you know, however, uh, this much is true: you know, uh, it's been recent sightings of, uh, human beings being, uh, shot up into the underbelly of alien spacecraft. You know, and speaking of the Bermuda Triangle... it's not technically a triangle.
Woody: It's not?
Cliff: Heck no! It's a trapazedarhomboid. Perfect for, uh, attracting Martian spacecraft.
 — From The Bar Stoolie, 1985.

When Cliff starts coming up with words like trapazedarhomboid, some viewers may find it easier to relate to the judgemental Carla than to the easy-going Norm.

Cliff Is Almost Heroically Well-Adjusted

Cliff Clavin annoys not just Carla and some of the show's viewers, he also annoys some of the other patrons in Cheers. In the season 2 episode Cliff's Rocky Moment, a patron gets so sick of hearing Cliff spew his trivia that he repeatedly challenges Cliff to a fist fight.

Years later, in the season 6 episode The Last Angry Mailman, Frasier Crane witnesses Cliff's mother Esther Clavin dispense dubious trivia — just like Cliff does sometimes — but even worse. This scene makes it apparent that, in the Clavin household, Cliff is the quiet one.

Upon seeing this, Frasier Crane — who is both a customer and a psychiatrist — remarks that Cliff seems almost heroically well-adjusted. Cliff and his Mom are a perfect example of the expression, the apple doesn't fall far from the tree.

Cliff and Sam's Similar Personalities

It may seem somewhat surprising to see that Cliff Clavin and Sam Malone, the manager and sometimes owner of Cheers, have similar personalities — and similar spiritual portraits. Although Cliff's image has much more Blue than Sam's — indicating Sam is more down-to-earth than Cliff — their portraits do share some similarities.

Many of the differences between Cliff and Sam are external and on the surface, rather than internal and part of their personality. For example, Sam was born with good looks and the ability to excel in sports. Meanwhile, Cliff was born to and grew up with a Mom who normalizes the annoying habit of sharing massive amounts of largely irrelevant trivia.

Good looks and reasonable Moms are not the sort of personality traits that show up in these spiritual portraits.

Moreover, if one compares Cliff's and Sam's outgoing, pragmatic, realistic, and open-minded personalities to the personalities of some of the other characters — Norm, Carla, Diane, and Lilith, for example — one realizes that relatively speaking, Cliff and Sam do indeed have somewhat similar temperaments.

Of course, that is strictly relatively speaking, and to be sure, to see the similarities one needs to look past the surface.

image_list.title: Frasier Crane
image_list.subtitle_html: Psychiatrist and Frequent Patron of Cheers
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Frasier Crane's spiritual portrait shows he is outgoing and has a moderate preference for being idealistic rather than pragmatic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Frasier's dominant personality trait, his openness to ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait when he chose to become a psychiatrist, which requires being comfortable with intangible theories and abstractions.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Frasier's auxiliary personality trait, his warmth and friendliness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait when he would spontaneously share his professional views on interpersonal issues with other people in Cheers, totally for free.
image_list.story_intro_html: Frasier Crane's spiritual portrait is fairly colorful, indicating his preferences are somewhat moderate. This is advantageous for a psychiatrist, because it makes ....
image_list.story_html:
Frasier Crane's spiritual portrait is fairly colorful, indicating his preferences are somewhat moderate. This is advantageous for a psychiatrist, because it makes it easier for him to relate to a variety of different people. Also, the Blue in his image represents his preference for abstractions over facts, which is another trait that can help him in this field of work.

Frasier and Diane

Cheers is originally about a romance between Sam Malone and Diane Chambers. After they have some ups-and-downs, Frasier and Diane date, and even become engaged. Frasier's and Diane's portraits look similar, and they do indeed have many shared interests, so it is easy to see how they could get along well.

Unfortunately for Frasier, this doesn't work out. This is surely due, at least in part, to the lack of Green and Red in Diane's portrait — which shows she can sometimes have difficulty making decisions.

After recovering from his broken heart, Frasier begins dating Lilith, whose personality is a far cry from Diane's.

Frasier and Lilith

Frasier meets Lilith Sternin, whose attitude, manner, clothes and hair style are all — a bit like her last name — exceedingly stern: serious, severe, formal and stiff. It's immediately obvious she is different not only from Diane, but also from the rest of the gang at Cheers.

Lilith's dress and manner are so extremely cold that, in the episode Where Have All the Floorboards Gone?, Carla suggests Lilith get the tension on that bun [in her hair] checked, because if that baby goes, we are dead!

After Diane gives Lilith a makeover and encourages her to let her hair down — both literally and figuratively — Frasier and Lilith begin a relationship. Once they put their rough start behind them, it turns out they get along well together, and they end up getting married.

Frasier and the Gang at Cheers

Frasier Crane's fairly colorful image shows his preferences are not as strong as Diane's and Lilith's. This makes it easier for him to fit in with Norm and Cliff and the rest of the gang at Cheers. Of course, his being male also helps him find common ground with the mostly-male patrons.

Frasier also fits in easily with modern day society as a whole. As a psychiatrist, his job is to listen to other people's problems all day, and he can plainly see and succinctly articulate what's wrong with the rat race:

Frasier: I would like to nominate as the stupidest creature on earth: the one who awakens each day to drive through gridlocked traffic, to sit in a windowless office breathing recirculated air, then returns home and collapses into a stupor, only to do the same damn thing all over again every day until he dies.
Norm: Looking forward to that vacation, hey Frase?
Frasier: You bet. We're going to Maui.
 — From Rebecca Redux, 1990.

It is around this time viewers learn that Lilith has close to three months of vacation time saved up. It's funny because it's unusual, but it's not surprising, because Lilith is quite unique.

I Can Relate

As someone who has a personality that is somewhat similar to Frasier Crane's, it is easier for me to relate to him than to any of the other characters on Cheers.

It's particularly easy to see how he could fall for Diane, whose personality is similar to both Frasier's and mine, then turn to Lilith, whose decisiveness is a welcome change from Diane's flakiness.

Finding Frasier Crane's character to be easier to empathize with than the others, it's nice to be able to actually see the similarities — and differences — in the personalities, as portrayed in these images.

image_list.title: Lilith Sternin
image_list.subtitle_html: Psychiatrist and Occasional Patron of Cheers
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Lilith Sternin's spiritual portrait shows she is introverted and extremely logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Lilith's dominant personality trait, her openness to ideas.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrated this trait when he chose to become a psychiatrist, which requires being comfortable with intangible theories and abstractions.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Lilith's auxiliary personality trait, her objectivity.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  She demonstrates this trait in her cool, aloof, scientific manner, that seems to be completely without any feeling.
image_list.story_intro_html: Lilith Sternin's spiritual portrait shows she is extremely rational. She rarely shows emotion, and even when she does — such as when her favorite....
image_list.story_html:
Lilith Sternin's spiritual portrait shows she is extremely rational. She rarely shows emotion, and even when she does — such as when her favorite lab rat dies — her expressions are very constrained.

Lilith and Frasier

Frasier Crane brings Lilith Sternin to Cheers on a date. Her last name, Sternin, is appropriate in that it reflects her stern, severe, stiff and serious attitude, manner, clothes and hair style — so at first the couple do not get along well.

Lilith's appearance and personality are so extreme that in the episode Where Have All the Floorboards Gone?, Carla suggests Lilith get the tension on that bun [in her hair] checked, because if that baby goes, we are dead!

In the episode Abnormal Psychology, Lilith gets a makeover from Diane Chambers, who gets Lilith to let her hair down â€” both literally and figuratively. At first Frasier is cynical, but once he sees her with her hair down, he reacts predictably — like some sort of Pavlovian dog — and insists they leave to be animals together.

Lilith and Betty Sternin

The Green in Lilith's spiritual portrait depicts how she can be brutally objective, and it becomes clear her relationship with Frasier survives only because he is willing to make compromises. At one point, though, they discuss the possibility of him dying before she does, and Frasier just can't take it anymore:

Lilith: It's healthy after a time to curtail one's grieving and recommence interest in the opposite sex. I know if my Frasier were taken from me in an unforeseen tragedy I would certainly date again after an acceptable period of bereavement.
Frasier: That gives me a warm fuzzy.
Lilith: There'd be no sense in being overly emotional, darling. You'd be dead and rotting in a box.
Frasier: Woody, can I have another beer and would you check on the robot over there and check if it's thirsty.
Woody: Hey Dr. Crane, that's your wife. Don't talk about her like that. What can I get you Dr. Sternin-Crane? Another quart of Valvoline?
Lilith: Oh won't you people stop it? I-am-not-a-robot!
 — From The Ghost and Mrs. LeBec, 1990.

The episode Smotherly Love lends some insight into why Lilith's personality is so extreme. Her mother Betty visits, complains about missing Lilith's wedding, and demands they re-marry for her benefit. Betty takes charge of everything, which quickly drives the decisive Lilith crazy.

Even the usually acid-tongued Carla is unable to find comebacks to Betty's authoritative pronouncements, but viewers eventually learn Betty has adopted this strong persona because that is how she was treated by her mom. Betty's domineering attitude ultimately causes Lilith to put her foot down and demand to be left alone — and it turns out this is just as Betty had planned it.

Lilith and Norm: Polar Opposites

Lilith Sternin and Norm Peterson are polar opposites. Where Lilith is reserved and decisive, Norm is outgoing and perceptive. Where she is interested in logic and scientific experiments, he is interested in beer and other people's drama.

And yet Lilith and Norm — to the extent they have any reason to talk — get along fine. This may indeed be because they live in such different worlds that neither of them has any call to judge the other.

Seeing how the extremely different personalities of Lilith and Norm can get along together is a reason for optimism.

If two people who have such extreme personalities and are so very different can manage to get along, maybe someday more evenly-balanced, normal people can someday figure out how to get along together as well.

And to be honest, this type of optimistic thinking is actually the whole purpose of this site!
